docs.lead_paragraph: I woke around midnight, threw up and went back to sleep. Nausea was nothing new. I had been throwing up constantly -- sometimes as often as 12 times a day -- throughout my pregnancy, but that night something felt different. If I had had to describe my symptoms right then, I would have resorted to the familiar vocabulary of illness -- I was dizzy, my heart was racing, I felt short of breath. I guess. The truth is, those words felt generic and crude, unequal to the task. What I felt was more elemental, as if my bodily organs -- mysterious, essential things I knew I had but couldn't feel -- had begun to malfunction in some subtle, unspeakable way. For the next few hours I lay on the bathroom floor throwing up, letting the tile cool my body as it shook uncontrollably after each episode, first freezing, then burning. A few hours later I got up, went into the bedroom and lay down next to my husband. I could tell from movement on the other side of the bed that he was awake. ''I'm scared,'' I said out loud.
docs.abstract: Rebecca Johnson article describes her pregnancy and diagnosis of pre-eclampsia; says it affects 7 percent of all pregnant women--usually in mild forms--and is one of leading causes of death among pregnant women worldwide; says there is little consensus about what causes it, how it works and, more important, how to treat it; tells sad outcome in her case: her child, Luke, died shortly after being born; photos (M)
docs.snippet: I woke around midnight, threw up and went back to sleep. Nausea was nothing new. I had been throwing up constantly -- sometimes as often as 12 times a day -- throughout my pregnancy, but that night something felt different. If I had had to describe...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN last we glimpsed Carmela Soprano -- in last season's finale of HBO's ''The Sopranos'' -- she was in the midst of trying to transform a life she realized was ''financed by crime,'' and appeared to be turning to New Jersey real estate. In a telling moment, Mrs. Soprano sat at a simple table in the McMansion that mob money bought and pored over a primer used by students preparing for the state licensing exam. When the new season begins in three weeks, ''she might as well join the crowd,'' laughed Edward Davies, director of the American School of Business. Mr. Davies's school offers the classes required for people who want to take the state test to become a real estate agent. ''Enrollment is through the roof right now,'' he said. ''We are taking down walls to expand classrooms, moving furniture -- anything we can do to accommodate people.''

headline.main: In the Region/New Jersey; Standing Room Only at Schools That Train Agents

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-14 The Struggle for Water Is Causing Global Tensions All across the world, the struggle for water is igniting social, economic and political tensions. The World Bank has said dwindling water supplies will be a major factor inhibiting economic growth, a subject being discussed at a weeklong international conference in South Africa starting tomorrow about balancing use of the world's resources against its economic needs. 1 U.S. Envoy Credits Pakistan Assistant Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage concluded a round of talks with leaders from Pakistan and India and credited Pakistan with reducing the cross-border infiltrations by Muslim guerrillas that have increased tensions between the nuclear-armed rivals. 11

docs.lead_paragraph: HAVING marched into history three months ago on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera, the tenor Salvatore Licitra has returned to northern Italy, where his career first took off, to spend his fifth consecutive summer in the open air at the mammoth Roman arena here, where unamplified opera on the scale of Cecil B. DeMille thrills international crowds of some 18,000. Comedy tonight? Hardly ever in Verona, and certainly not in Mr. Licitra's corner of the repertory. This summer he played Radames, leader of the Egyptian army, in Verdi's ''Aida,'' a role new to him. The production, also new, was by Franco Zeffirelli, operating in appropriately pharaonic dimensions.

headline.main: A Superstar's Fill-In Is a Star on His Own Back Home in Italy

docs.abstract: Salvatore Licitra, who drew rave reviews as last-minute replacement for Luciano Pavarotti in Metropolitan Opera production of Tosca three months ago, has returned to northern Italy to spend his fifth consecutive summer in open air at mammoth Roman arena in Verona, playing Radames in Verdi's Aida, role new to him in new production by Franco Zeffirelli; cheering fans adore him; his next American appearance will be on Sept 11, when he joins Zdenek Macal, New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, Westminster Symphonic Choir and other starry soloists in free commemorative Verdi Requiem at Liberty State Park in New Jersey; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Around the country this summer, at least half a dozen hospitals have closed obstetric wards, others have curtailed trauma services, and a string of rural clinics have been temporarily shuttered as a result of soaring costs for medical malpractice insurance. Mercy Hospital in West Philadelphia closed its maternity ward on Friday, and the Largo Medical Center, near Tampa, Fla., plans to do so in December.

headline.main: RISE IN INSURANCE FORCES HOSPITALS TO SHUTTER WARDS

docs.abstract: Soaring costs for medical malpractice insurance prompt hospitals around country to close maternity wards and curtail trauma services, and temporarily shutter string of rural clinics; hospital administrators say increasing malpractice costs first led doctors to order batteries of costly exams and limit risky procedures, or to retire early, and now is directly affecting medical institutions and care they deliver to patients; in all, more than 1,300 health care institutions have already been affected; so far no deaths ahve been attributed to cutback, but hospitals say risks to patients are rising; rising awards by juries in medical malpractice lawsuits seen as major factor in skyrocketing insurance premiums; photos; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Around the country this summer, at least half a dozen hospitals have closed obstetric wards, others have curtailed trauma services, and a string of rural clinics have been temporarily shuttered as a result of soaring costs for medical malpractice...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tony Mazzocchi, the driving force behind the nation's fledgling Labor Party, shocked thousands of the party's members when he recently wrote to them, ''I am both afflicted with an incurable disease and blessed with an incurable optimism.'' Mr. Mazzocchi, 76, has pancreatic cancer, and although his doctors give him only a few weeks or maybe a few months to live, he continues to battle relentlessly in pursuit of his dream -- building a Labor Party that will someday move to center stage in American politics.

headline.main: Facing Death, Founder Fights for Labor Party's Life

docs.lead_paragraph: Caroline Spencer Williams, the daughter of Katherine and Walter Williams of Wellesley Hills, Mass., is to be married today to Jeffrey Robert Melby, a son of Judith and John Melby of LaGrangeville, N.Y. The Rev. Colin L. Leitch, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to officiate at Castle Hill, a historic house in Ipswich, Mass. The bride, 25, is a quality-improvement specialist at Tufts Health Plan, an insurance company in Watertown, Mass. She graduated from Emmanuel College in Boston. Her father is a partner in the Wellesley Hills office of Battalia Winston International, an executive search firm. Her mother is an interviewer in the admissions office of Wellesley College.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the two and a half years since Luis Jiménez arrived at the Martin Memorial Medical Center emergency room with severe brain damage from a head-on car collision, the hospital here has become his home. In that time, Mr. Jiménez, 30, a former gardener, has emerged from a coma, had two birthdays and accumulated medical bills of almost $1 million. By all accounts, he is well enough to be discharged, but the hospital and advocates for the patient are in a conflict over his mounting medical bills and future care that makes his release unlikely without a court order.

headline.main: Hospitals Feeling Strain From Illegal Immigrants

docs.abstract: Article on national debate over who is ultimately responsible for illegal immigrants who require extensive medical care but have no means to pay for it; issue has become increasing concern for health care providers, particularly in Florida and border states with growing numbers of illegal immigrants; photo of Luis Jimenez, illegal alien who has spent over two years in hospital in Stuart, Fla, after suffering severe brain damage in car crash; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Judge Freezes Accounts Of Ex-Enron Executive A Houston magistrate has signed orders freezing a number of brokerage and bank accounts controlled by Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, and members of his family, people involved in the case said. The orders were signed by United States Magistrate Calvin Botley after some family members tried to move millions from one account to another, these people said. [Page C2.] Insurers Halt Coverage on Big Vans After rollover crashes of 15-passenger vans involving death and injury to sports teams, choirs and campers, a growing number of colleges and churches are prohibiting or severely limiting their use, and some insurance companies are refusing to insure them. [A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove set a special session of the Legislature for Sept. 5 to address proposals to make medical malpractice insurance more affordable for doctors. Governor Musgrove, a Democrat, said that if lawmakers passed a malpractice plan, which is likely to include some state-run insurance, he would open the agenda to other tort issues like caps on jury awards.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Affordable Malpractice Coverage
